p: The variations in the antimicrobial potencies among the different honeys reported to be more than 100-folds, which is attributed to their botanical and geographical origins ( Molan and Cooper, 2000). Such variations in the properties of honeys could be responsible for the broadly varying capabilities of honeys to serve as antioxidants ( Lusby et al., 2005; French et al., 2005; Mullai & Menon 2007). The antimicrobial property of honey is mainly attributed to osmolality (sugar), pH, hydrogen peroxide levels and the methylglyoxal ( Mavric et al., 2008, Alvarez-Suarez et al., 2010a). Moreover, the honey’s non-peroxide aspects such as: lysozyme, some phytochemicals, phenolic acids and flavonoids are reported to play important role in its antimicrobial properties ( Al et al., 2009). Particularly, the presence of phenolic compounds in honey, their anti-oxidant properties and their positive health role have been well documented ( Gheldof and Engeseth, 2002, Nicholls and Miraglio, 2003). Moreover, the presence of differences in the amount of phenolic compounds based on its botanical and geographical origins have been also reported ( Özkök et al. 2010).
